writing_prompt: Years after their childhood hero, the shortstop, was traded away, two old friends reunite and unexpectedly find themselves reliving the rituals of their youth, grappling with what was lost and what still remains.
story:
We were in Jimmy's backyard playing Wiffle ball when the news broke that the shortstop had been traded. It was a sweltering summer afternoon, the sky a brilliant blue that seemed to vibrate with the sound of our laughter and shouts. The Wiffle ball flew back and forth between us, its yellow and red stripes a blur as we chased after it, our sneakers scuffling against the grass. Our parents sat on the patio, sipping lemonade and watching us with knowing smiles. It was a moment frozen in time, one that we would replay in our minds for years to come, a snapshot of innocence and joy that we would never truly recapture.

The shortstop's trade was a shock, a betrayal that cut deep. We had grown up watching him play, idolizing him for his lightning-quick reflexes and his uncanny ability to make impossible plays. He was more than just a player – he was a hero, a symbol of what it meant to be a true champion. And now, in an instant, he was gone, leaving us with a sense of loss and disillusionment that would take years to process.

As we grew older, our lives took us in different directions. We went to different colleges, started different careers, and made new friends. But the memory of that summer, of the shortstop and the Wiffle ball, remained with us, a bittersweet reminder of what we had lost and what we still longed for.

Years later, I found myself standing in line at Disney World, waiting to ride the Space Mountain roller coaster. I had always loved this ride, the way it twisted and turned through the dark, the sense of weightlessness that came with the first drop. As I waited, I noticed a familiar face in front of me – it was Jimmy, my old friend from the Wiffle ball days.

We exchanged tentative smiles, and I felt a surge of nostalgia wash over me. We hadn't seen each other in years, and yet, in that moment, it felt like no time had passed at all. We chatted briefly about our lives, about our jobs and our families, but it was clear that we both knew why we were really there – to relive the past, to recapture the magic of our childhood.

As we rode the roller coaster, the wind whipping through our hair, I felt a sense of freedom that I hadn't experienced in years. We screamed and laughed together, our faces pressed against the safety bar, and for a moment, it felt like we were kids again, carefree and untethered.

But as the ride came to an end, and we stumbled out into the bright sunlight, reality set in. We were no longer kids, no longer carefree. We were adults, with responsibilities and worries and fears. And yet, as we stood there, looking at each other, I knew that we both felt the same thing – a deep longing for what we had lost, for the innocence and joy of our childhood.

We decided to grab some lunch, and as we walked through the crowds of tourists, I couldn't help but notice the little things – the way the sunlight danced through the leaves of the trees, the sound of the seagulls crying overhead. It was all so familiar, so nostalgic, that I felt my heart swell with emotion.

We found a small café, tucked away in a corner of the park, and sat down at a table by the window. As we ate our sandwiches, I couldn't help but think about the shortstop, about the way he used to play. I remembered his pre-pitch routine, the way he would tap his chest and his hip, the way he would rattle his wristband and his bat. It was a ritual, a symbol of his focus and his determination, and it was something that I had always admired.

As I thought about it, I realized that the shortstop's routine was more than just a quirk – it was a metaphor for our own lives. We had all grown up with our own rituals, our own ways of coping with the world. For some of us, it was a morning run, or a quiet moment of meditation. For others, it was a cup of coffee, or a good book. But for the shortstop, it was that pre-pitch routine, a series of taps and touches that helped him focus, that helped him prepare for the game.

As I looked at Jimmy, I knew that he understood what I was saying. We both knew that our own rituals, our own ways of coping, were a reflection of our own inner lives. We were searching for meaning, for purpose, in a world that often seemed chaotic and uncertain.

As we finished our lunch, and prepared to part ways, I felt a sense of sadness wash over me. I knew that we would never be kids again, that we would never recapture the magic of our childhood. But I also knew that we had something more important – we had each other, and the memories of our past. We had the shortstop, and the Wiffle ball, and the rituals that had brought us together.

As I watched Jimmy walk away, I felt a sense of peace settle over me. I knew that I would always carry the memories of our childhood with me, that I would always cherish the moments we had shared. And I knew that, no matter where life took me, I would always have the shortstop, and his pre-pitch routine, to remind me of what was lost, and what still remains.
